Description: Papyrus written with black ink with demotic legal text and list of tombs on recto (26 ll.) and verso (1 l.). Dated dated to year 6, Payni 11, presumably of Ptolemy VI (175 BC).
Curator's comments: This document is part of a family archive associated with Panas, son of Espmetis, a mortuary priest and moneylender. Panas’ archive contains documents from his own business (between 180-157 BC), his father Espmetis’ business (between 239-223 BC) and Panas’ wife Tathoytis (from 175 BC). Papyri from Panas’ archive are held by multiple institutions, the British Museum holdings are: EA10388; EA10532; EA10556,1-4; EA10557; EA10612; EA10613; EA10614; EA10615,1-3; EA10670,1-7; EA10823 and EA10824. Panas also appears in documentation from other family archives, including that of Pechytes, son of Pchorchonsis, and what is known as the ‘Anonymous’ family archive. For a full list of associated documents and their relationship with Panas: https://www.trismegistos.org/arch/archives/pdf/446.pdf https://www.trismegistos.org/arch/detail.php?quick=446 P.W. Pestman, 1995. ‘A family archive which changes history’, in S.P. Vleeming Hundred-gated Thebes: acts of a colloquium on Thebes and the Theban area in the Graeco-Roman period B. Muhs, 2005. Tax receipts, taxpayers, and taxes in early Ptolemaic Thebes

Thompson's MS Catalogue: "a list of tombs with an agreement for the division of them between two women, Ta-THwt and T-Sr.t-THwt. Date. year 6 Payni 1(1?) of an unnamed King. Origin Thebes or Gebelen (?)". Demotic list of tombs, dated to year 6, Payni 11, presumably of Ptolemy VI (175 BC). The date is followed by a heading “(1) Tathotes has agreed (mtr) with Senthotes her sister to divide (r pS) the burial places among themselves. (2) The list of the burial places which have fallen (to) her among them”. The heading is followed by a list of tombs, an agreement to divide according to oath, and a penalty for violating the oath. Pestman assigned this papyrus to the archive of Panas because it was acquired along with several other papyri clearly belonging to Panas. There is not secure link to Panas, but contracts from another archive naming the daughters indicate that he was married to a woman named Tathotes, who could be the Tathotes named here.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1990a / Catalogue of Demotic Papyri in the British Museum IV: Ptolemaic Legal Texts from the Theban Area (p.73-4, pl.61, 66)
Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (48642) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/48642)
Pestman 1993 / The Archive of the Theban Choachytes (second century BC). A Survey of the Demotic and Greek Papyri Contained in the Archive (24, 85 (Text 15), 292 and 294.)
Muhs 2014/2015 / More Papyri from the Archive of Panas Son of Espemetis (90-91)
